dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Afterpay's valuation has absolutely cratered, from 18 billion down to just one billion.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Afterpay's valuation has absolutely cratered, from eighteen billion down to just one billion.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Australian company Afterpay, whose entire business is staked on the scheme, has sailed from a market valuation of $1 billion in 2018 to $18 billion today.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Oh wow, that is a massive drop. And now Visa's pulling back too with this new Pay in 12 product.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh wow, that is a massive drop. And now Visa's pulling back too with this new Pay in twelve product.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Now PayPal PYPL -0.3% is cramming into the space. Its new Pay in 4 product will let you pay for any items that cost between $30 and $600 in four installments over six weeks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it's offering zero interest, which is a huge difference from Afterpay's like, what, up to 30 percent interest?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it's offering zero interest, which is a huge difference from Afterpay's like, what, up to thirty percent interest?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It doesnt charge interest to the consumer, but if youre late on a payment, youll pay fees. Affirm also charges retailers transaction fees. But most of the time, it makes users pay interest of 10 - 30%, and it has no late fees.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, and they're even giving 10 percent cash back? That's wild. But then the article mentions Visa's actually deeply in debt itself.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly, and they're even giving ten percent cash back? That's wild. But then the article mentions Visa's actually deeply in debt itself.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and their payment network is apparently unprofitable—they can't even leverage it properly. And get this, fewer than 10 percent of top U.S. retailers even accept Visa.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and their payment network is apparently unprofitable-they can't even leverage it properly. And get this, fewer than ten percent of top U.S. retailers even accept Visa.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: PayPal can undercut the competition on fees because it already has a dominant, highly profitable payments network it can leverage. Eighty percent of the top 100 retailers in the U.S. let customers pay with PayPal, and nearly 70% of U.S. online buyers have PayPal accounts.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: That's shockingly low. And during the pandemic, even with record revenues, they still posted losses—15 million in Q2.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's shockingly low. And during the pandemic, even with record revenues, they still posted lossesminus fifteen million in Q2.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: PayPal charges retailers per-transaction fees of 2.9% plus $0.30, and in the second quarter, as Covid-19 made online purchases skyrocket, it saw record revenues of $5.3 billion and profits of $1.5 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And Elon Musk quote there, saying Visa will shrink 18-19 percent before it even gets out of bed? Harsh.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Elon Musk quote there, saying Visa will shrink eighteen to nineteen percent before it even gets out of bed? Harsh.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In an economic environment where ecommerce is surging, PayPal can grow 18-19% before it gets out of bed in the morning, says Lisa Ellis, an analyst at MoffettNathanson.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and the data shows consumers spend way less when they use point-of-sale financing—like 20 percent less sometimes.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and the data shows consumers spend way less when they use point-of-sale financing-like twenty percent less sometimes.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Data from Afterpay and PayPal show that consumers spend more moneysometimes 20% morewhen theyre offered point of sale financing options.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So if transaction sizes plummet with Pay in 12, and Visa only earns 0.29 percent per transaction, their fee revenue is gonna take a huge hit.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So if transaction sizes plummet with Pay in twelve, and Visa only earns zero point two nine percent per transaction, their fee revenue is gonna take a huge hit.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: PayPal charges retailers per-transaction fees of 2.9% plus $0.30, and in the second quarter, as Covid-19 made online purchases skyrocket, it saw record revenues of $5.3 billion and profits of $1.5 billion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And the market for this is tiny so far—Afterpay only has 56 users in the U.S., Affirm claims the same.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the market for this is tiny so far-Afterpay only has fifty six users in the U.S., Affirm claims the same.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Afterpay, which expanded to the U.S. in 2018, has 5.6 million users. Affirm also says it has 5.6 million.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's interesting though, Visa's been in this space for a while with Visa UnCredit, which offers negative interest rates? That's basically paying people to borrow.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's interesting though, Visa's been in this space for a while with Visa UnCredit, which offers negative interest rates? That's basically paying people to borrow.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Separate from Pay in 4, PayPal has been offering point of sale financing for more than a decade. It bought Baltimore startup Bill Me Later in 2008 and rebranded it as PayPal Credit in 2014.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, almost like a charity, and they offload those loans to HSBC. But with Pay in 12, they're outsourcing the new loans to the Cayman Islands.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, almost like a charity, and they offload those loans to H S B C. But with Pay in twelve, they're outsourcing the new loans to the Cayman Islands.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: it offloads the U.S. loans to Synchrony Bank. Unlike PayPal Credit, PayPal will house these new loans on its own balance sheet.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Their SVP Doug Bland even admitted they took incredibly irresponsible actions during the pandemic with lending.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Their S V P Doug Bland even admitted they took incredibly irresponsible actions during the pandemic with lending.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: PayPal senior vice president Doug Bland says, We took prudent, responsible action from a risk perspective.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So it sounds like they're trying to play it safer now, but still diving into a super risky product.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So it sounds like they're trying to play it safer now, but still diving into a super risky product.

artist_script:
HostA: Afterpay's valuation has absolutely cratered, from 18 billion down to just one billion.
HostB: Oh wow, that is a massive drop. And now Visa's pulling back too with this new Pay in 12 product.
HostA: Yeah, and it's offering zero interest, which is a huge difference from Afterpay's like, what, up to 30 percent interest?
HostB: Exactly, and they're even giving 10 percent cash back? That's wild. But then the article mentions Visa's actually deeply in debt itself.
HostA: Right, and their payment network is apparently unprofitable—they can't even leverage it properly. And get this, fewer than 10 percent of top U.S. retailers even accept Visa.
HostB: That's shockingly low. And during the pandemic, even with record revenues, they still posted losses—15 million in Q2.
HostA: And Elon Musk quote there, saying Visa will shrink 18-19 percent before it even gets out of bed? Harsh.
HostB: Yeah, and the data shows consumers spend way less when they use point-of-sale financing—like 20 percent less sometimes.
HostA: So if transaction sizes plummet with Pay in 12, and Visa only earns 0.29 percent per transaction, their fee revenue is gonna take a huge hit.
HostB: And the market for this is tiny so far—Afterpay only has 56 users in the U.S., Affirm claims the same.
HostA: It's interesting though, Visa's been in this space for a while with Visa UnCredit, which offers negative interest rates? That's basically paying people to borrow.
HostB: Yeah, almost like a charity, and they offload those loans to HSBC. But with Pay in 12, they're outsourcing the new loans to the Cayman Islands.
HostA: Their SVP Doug Bland even admitted they took incredibly irresponsible actions during the pandemic with lending.
HostB: So it sounds like they're trying to play it safer now, but still diving into a super risky product.
